overview: This measure transfers the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services. [9] The S.D. 1 version renames the office to "Broadband Office", changes the "Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund" to the "Broadband Revolving Fund", and repeals the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council. [9] [9] [9] It also repeals broadband duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. [8]
appropriations: The legislative document specifies an appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) out of the general revenues for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [8] The bill also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) from the broadband revolving fund for the reimbursement of contracts executed by the broadband office. [8] An additional blank appropriation is included for the establishment of an unspecified number of full-time equivalent digital navigator positions. [8]
assumptions_and_methodology: Testimony proposes a one-time appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) for the reimbursement of contracts to enable timely reimbursement to non-profit organizations while the Broadband Office draws down on federal funding. [7] The intent is to return the full amount back to the General Fund in 5 years. [7] The Office of Enterprise Technology Services bases its request for a larger budget on the HBDEO’s Form A request for Fiscal Year 25-27. [7]
agency_impact: The Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS) states that taking over the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office will be a huge endeavor and that current ETS resources are focused internally to government. [7] [7] The Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs supports the bill and requests amendments to consolidate the state’s broadband functions into the HBDEO through the repeal of HRS Section 440G-11.5 and Act 199, Section 3. [7] The Department finds it prudent to consolidate duties under one state agency to conserve taxpayer resources and reduce confusion. [7] [7]
economic_impact: The federal and state governments have committed over $400 million (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) to modernize subsea and terrestrial infrastructure. [7] Hawaii is slated to receive over $200 million in federal grants for broadband infrastructure in the immediate future via the Broadband, Equity, Access, and Deployment Program. [7] With the construction of new subsea broadband infrastructure, the State anticipates generating revenue from negotiated lease agreements. [9]
policy_impact: The S.D. 1 version of the bill repeals Chapter 206S, Hawaii Revised Statutes, and section 440G-11.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes. [8] [8] It also repeals Act 199, Session Laws of Hawaii 2010, which established the broadband assistance advisory council. [8] The measure renames the "Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office" to "Broadband Office" and changes the "Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund" to the "Broadband Revolving Fund". [9] [9]
revenue_sources: The bill establishes the broadband revolving fund in the state treasury to be administered by the broadband office. [8] The fund will consist of proceeds of leases of broadband infrastructure owned by the State, appropriations by the legislature, and gifts, donations, and grants. [8] [8] The legislative document specifies that $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) in general revenues shall be deposited into the fund for fiscal year 2025-2026. [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: Testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS) indicates the HBDEO's current budget is $360,000 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) to fund four staff, and the office has been operating with essentially no operating expenses for the past two fiscal years. [7] [7] ETS states the HBDEO had asked for $777,090 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 26, consisting of $452,302 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) for personal services and $324,788 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) for other expenses. [7] ETS asks that this funding be included in the bill to ensure the transfer is successful. [7] [7] The S.D. 1 version of the bill appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) from general revenues for FY 2025-2026 to be deposited into the new broadband revolving fund. [8] It also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) from the revolving fund in FY 2025-2026 for the reimbursement of contracts. [8] Testimony indicates the intent is to return the $200,000 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) general fund appropriation back to the General Fund in 5 years. [7] The bill also includes a blank appropriation to establish digital navigator positions. [9]
operating_revenue_impact: With the construction of new subsea broadband infrastructure, the State anticipates generating revenue from negotiated lease agreements. [7] The bill specifies that proceeds of leases of broadband infrastructure owned by the State shall be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [8] The creation of a separate fund will ensure these funds are used to reduce the cost of internet services and support broadband projects. [9]
capital_expenditure_impact: The Broadband and Digital Equity Special Fund is intended to prioritize funding for projects related to broadband adoption and affordability programs, rather than retail infrastructure projects. [7] [7] Testimony was received expressing concern with language excluding the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service, stating the term is undefined and could restrict community-led initiatives. [7] [7] [7] Other testimony notes the intent of the amendment was to ensure that new competition enters the market on a fair and equal playing field. [7]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The establishment of the fund is intended to support long term sustainability of the state's broadband infrastructure assets. [7] [7] Testimony from the Lieutenant Governor's office states the intent is to return the full amount of the one-time appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_HD1_TESTIMONY_EDT_03-11-25_.PDF.txt) back to the General Fund in 5 years. [7] The revolving fund is expected to be sustained by sources including proceeds from leases of state-owned broadband infrastructure. [8]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The bill has been amended to S.D. 1, which renames the office to 'Broadband Office' and changes the 'Special Fund' to a 'Broadband Revolving Fund'. [9] [9] The measure now repeals the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council and repeals broadband-related duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. [9] [9] The appropriation has been changed from an unspecified amount to a specific appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_SD1_SSCR1126_.htm.txt) from general revenues for FY26, with the stated intent to return the funds in 5 years. [9] [7] A new appropriation of $200,000 (HB934_SD1_.HTM.txt) from the revolving fund is also included for contract reimbursement. [8] New testimony from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs expresses support for consolidating broadband duties under the new office. [7] [7]
